Communication-efficient Vertical Federated Learning via Compressed Error Feedback

Anonymous Author(s)
Affiliation 111Full affiliation    Pedro Valdeira222Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University; email: pvaldeira@cmu.edu. 333Institute for Systems and Robotics, Instituto Superior Técnico.
CMU & IST    João Xavier†
IST    Cláudia Soares444Department of Computer Science, NOVA School of Science and Technology.
NOVA    Yuejie Chi∗
CMU
Abstract

Communication overhead is a known bottleneck in federated learning (FL). To address this, lossy compression is commonly used on the information communicated between the server and clients during training. In horizontal FL, where each client holds a subset of the samples, such communication-compressed training methods have recently seen significant progress. However, in their vertical FL counterparts, where each client holds a subset of the features, our understanding remains limited. To address this, we propose an error feedback compressed vertical federated learning (EFVFL) method to train split neural networks. In contrast with previous communication-compressed methods for vertical FL, EFVFL does not require a vanishing compression error for the gradient norm to converge to zero for smooth nonconvex problems. By leveraging error feedback, our method can achieve a 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T) convergence rate in the full-batch case, improving over the state-of-the-art 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) rate under 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) compression error, and matching the rate of uncompressed methods. Further, when the objective function satisfies the Polyak-Łojasiewicz inequality, our method converges linearly. In addition to improving convergence rates, our method also supports the use of private labels. Numerical experiments show that EFVFL significantly improves over the prior art, confirming our theoretical results.

44footnotetext: A preliminary version of this work was accepted for publication at EUSIPCO 2024 (Valdeira et al., 2024).

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a machine learning paradigm where a set of clients holding local datasets collaborate to train a model without exposing their local data (McMahan et al., 2017). FL can be divided into two categories, based on how the data is partitioned across the clients: horizontal FL, where each client holds a different set of samples but all clients share the same features, and vertical FL, where each client holds a different subset of features but all clients share the same samples. Note that we cannot gather and redistribute the data because it must remain at the clients. Thus, we do not choose under which category a given task falls. Rather, the category is a consequence of how the data arises.

In this work, we focus on vertical FL (VFL) (Liu et al., 2024). In VFL, a global dataset 𝒟={𝝃n}n=1N𝒟superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝃𝑛𝑛1𝑁\mathcal{D}=\{\bm{\xi}_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N} with N𝑁N samples is partitioned by features across a set of clients [K]≔{1,…,K}≔delimited-[]𝐾1…𝐾[K]\coloneqq\{1,\dots,K\}. Each sample has K𝐾K disjoint blocks of features 𝝃n=(𝝃n​1,…,𝝃n​K)subscript𝝃𝑛subscript𝝃𝑛1…subscript𝝃𝑛𝐾\bm{\xi}_{n}=(\bm{\xi}_{n1},\dots,\bm{\xi}_{nK}) and the local dataset of each client k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] is 𝒟k={𝝃n​k}n=1Nsubscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝝃𝑛𝑘𝑛1𝑁\mathcal{D}_{k}=\{\bm{\xi}_{nk}\}_{n=1}^{N}, where 𝒟=⋃k𝒟k𝒟subscript𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}=\bigcup_{k}\mathcal{D}_{k}. Since different datasets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} have different features, VFL suits collaborations of clients with complementary types of information, who tend to have fewer competing interests. This can lead to a greater incentive to collaborate, compared to horizontal FL. A common application of VFL is in settings where multiple entities own distinct features concerning a shared set of users and seek to collaboratively train a predictor; for example, WeBank partners with other companies to jointly build a risk model from data regarding shared customers (Cheng et al., 2020).

To jointly train a model from {𝒟k}subscript𝒟𝑘\{\mathcal{D}_{k}\} without sharing local data, split neural networks (Ceballos et al., 2020) are often considered. To learn the parameters 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} of such models, we aim to solve the following nonconvex optimization problem:

min𝒙∈ℝd⁡f​(𝒙)≔1N​∑n=1Nϕn​(𝒙0,𝒉1​n​(𝒙1),…,𝒉K​n​(𝒙K)),≔subscript𝒙superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝒙1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛subscript𝒙0subscript𝒉1𝑛subscript𝒙1…subscript𝒉𝐾𝑛subscript𝒙𝐾\min_{\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\;f(\bm{x})\coloneqq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\phi_{n}\left(\bm{x}_{0},\bm{h}_{1n}(\bm{x}_{1}),\dots,\bm{h}_{Kn}(\bm{x}_{K})\right), (1)

where 𝒙≔(𝒙0,𝒙1,…,𝒙K)≔𝒙subscript𝒙0subscript𝒙1…subscript𝒙𝐾\bm{x}\coloneqq(\bm{x}_{0},\bm{x}_{1},\dots,\bm{x}_{K}). Here, 𝒉k​n​(𝒙k)≔𝒉k​(𝒙k;𝝃n​k)≔subscript𝒉𝑘𝑛subscript𝒙𝑘subscript𝒉𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘subscript𝝃𝑛𝑘\bm{h}_{kn}(\bm{x}_{k})\coloneqq\bm{h}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k};\bm{\xi}_{nk}) is the local model of client k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], which is parameterized by 𝒙ksubscript𝒙𝑘\bm{x}_{k} and extracts an (often lower-dimensional) representation of 𝝃n​ksubscript𝝃𝑛𝑘\bm{\xi}_{nk}. These representations, or embeddings, are then sent to the server. The server, in turn, uses {𝒉k​n​(𝒙k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑛subscript𝒙𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\bm{h}_{kn}(\bm{x}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K} as input to ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n}, which corresponds to the composition of the loss function and the server model and is parameterized by 𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{x}_{0}.555The server often aggregates the representations 𝒉k​nsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑛\bm{h}_{kn} via some nonparameterized operation (for example, a sum or an average) before inputting them into the server model. We consider this aggregation to be included in ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n}.

Most FL methods, including ours, assume that the server can communicate with all the clients and that the clients do not communicate with each other. These methods typically require many rounds of client-server communications. Such communications can significantly slow down training. In fact, they can become the main bottleneck during training (Dean et al., 2012, Lian et al., 2017). To address this, a plethora of communication-efficient FL methods have been proposed. In particular, a popular technique to mitigate the communication overhead is lossy compression. Compression operators, or simply compressors, are operators that map a given vector into another vector that is easier to communicate (that is, requires fewer bits).

Optimization methods employing communication compression have seen great success (Seide et al., 2014, Alistarh et al., 2017). Most of these works focus on the prevalent horizontal FL setup and thus consider gradient compression, as these are the vectors being communicated in the horizontal setting (Alistarh et al., 2018, Stich et al., 2018). Yet, in vertical FL, the clients send representations {𝒉k​n​(𝒙k)}subscript𝒉𝑘𝑛subscript𝒙𝑘\{\bm{h}_{kn}(\bm{x}_{k})\} instead. In contrast to gradient compression, compressing these intermediate representations leads the compression-induced error to undergo a nonlinear function ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n} before impacting gradient-based updates. Thus, compression in VFL is not covered by these works and our understanding of it remains limited. In fact, to the best of our knowledge, Castiglia et al. (2022) is the only work providing convergence guarantees for compressed VFL. Yet, Castiglia et al. (2022) employs a direct compression method, requiring the compression error to go to zero as the number of gradient steps T𝑇T increases, achieving a 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) rate when the compression error is 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}). This makes the method in Castiglia et al. (2022) unsuitable for applications with strict per-round communication limitations, such as bandwidth constraints, and leads to the following question:

Can we design a communication-compressed VFL method that preserves the convergence rate of uncompressed methods without decreasing the amount of compression as training progresses?

1.1 Our contributions

In this work, we answer the question above in the affirmative. Our main contributions are as follows.

  • •

    We propose error feedback compressed VFL (EFVFL), which leverages an error feedback technique to improve the stability of communication-compressed training in VFL.

  • •

    We show that our method achieves a convergence rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T) for nonconvex objectives under nonvanishing compression error, improving over the state-of-the-art 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) rate under 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) compression error of Castiglia et al. (2022), and matching the rate of the centralized setting. We further show that, under the Polyak-Łojasiewicz (PL) inequality, our method converges linearly, thus obtaining the first linearly convergent compressed VFL method. Unlike the method in Castiglia et al. (2022), EFVFL supports the use of private labels, broadening its applicability.

  • •

    We run numerical experiments and observe empirically that our method improves the state-of-the-art, achieving a better communication efficiency than existing methods.

1.2 Related work

Communication-efficient FL.

The aforementioned communication bottleneck in FL (Lian et al., 2017) makes communication-efficient methods a particularly active area of research. FL methods often employ multiple local updates between rounds of communication, use only a subset of the clients at a time (McMahan et al., 2017), or even update the global model asynchronously (Xie et al., 2019). Another line of research considers fully decentralized methods (Lian et al., 2017), dispensing with the server and, instead, exploiting communications between clients. This can alleviate the bandwidth limit ensuing from the centralized role of the server. Another popular technique is lossy compression, which is the focus of this work.

Communication-compressed optimization methods can exploit different families of compressors. A popular choice is the family of unbiased compressors (Alistarh et al., 2017), which is appealing in that its properties facilitate the theoretical analysis of the resulting methods. Yet, some widely adopted compressors do not belong to this class, such as top-k𝑘k sparsification (Alistarh et al., 2018, Stich et al., 2018) and deterministic rounding (Sapio et al., 2021). Thus, the broader family of contractive compressors (Beznosikov et al., 2023) has recently attracted a lot of attention. Yet, methods employing them for direct compression are often prone to instability or even divergence (Beznosikov et al., 2023). To address this, error feedback techniques have been proposed; first, as a heuristic (Seide et al., 2014), but, more recently, significant progress has been made on our theoretical understanding of the application of these methods to gradient compression (Stich et al., 2018, Alistarh et al., 2018, Richtárik et al., 2021). In the horizontal setting, some works have combined error feedback compression with the aforementioned communication-efficient techniques, such as communication-compressed fully decentralized methods (Koloskova et al., 2019, Zhao et al., 2022).

Vertical FL.

To mitigate the communication bottleneck in VFL, we often employ techniques akin to those used in horizontal FL. In particular, Liu et al. (2022) performed multiple local updates between communication rounds, Chen et al. (2020) updated the local models asynchronously, and Ying et al. (2018) proposed a fully decentralized approach. Recently, Valdeira et al. (2023) proposed a semi-decentralized method leveraging both client-server and client-client communications to avoid the slow convergence of fully-decentralized methods on large and sparse networks while alleviating the server bottleneck.

In this work, we focus on communication-compressed methods tailored to VFL. While, as mentioned above, most work in communication-compressed methods focuses on gradient compression and thus does not apply directly to VFL, recently, a few empirical works on VFL have employed compression. Namely, Khan et al. (2022) compressed the local data before sending it to the server, where the model is trained, and Li et al. (2020) proposed an asynchronous method with bidirectional (sparse) gradient compression. Nevertheless, Castiglia et al. (2022), where direct compression is used, is the only work on compressed VFL with theoretical guarantees. For a more a detailed discussion on VFL, see Liu et al. (2024), Yang et al. (2023).

2 Preliminaries

We now define the class of contractive compressors, which we consider throughout this paper.

Definition 1 (Contractive compressor).

A map 𝒞:ℝd↦ℝd:𝒞maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R}^{d} is a contractive compressor if there exists α∈(0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in(0,1] such that,666In Definition 1, we use a common, simplified notation, omitting the randomness in 𝒞:ℝd×Ω→ℝd:𝒞→superscriptℝ𝑑Ωsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\Omega\to\mathbb{R}^{d}. We assume that the randomness ω𝜔\omega in 𝒞​(𝐯,ω)𝒞𝐯𝜔\mathcal{C}(\bm{v},\omega) at different applications of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is independent.

∀𝒗∈ℝd:𝔼∥𝒞(𝒗)−𝒗∥2≤(1−α)∥𝒗∥2,\forall\bm{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\quad\mathbb{E}\lVert\mathcal{C}(\bm{v})-\bm{v}\rVert^{2}\leq(1-\alpha)\lVert\bm{v}\rVert^{2}, (2)

where the expectation is taken with respect to the (possible) randomness in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}.

2.1 Error feedback

Error feedback is useful when using compressed communications to send a sequence of vectors {𝒗t}superscript𝒗𝑡\{\bm{v}^{t}\} which we expect to converge. Unlike direct compression, where each 𝒗tsuperscript𝒗𝑡\bm{v}^{t} is compressed independently and 𝒞​(𝒗t)𝒞superscript𝒗𝑡\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t}) acts as a surrogate for 𝒗tsuperscript𝒗𝑡\bm{v}^{t}, in error feedback compression, an estimate 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} is used as a surrogate. This surrogate is initialized as 𝒔0=𝒞​(𝒗0)superscript𝒔0𝒞superscript𝒗0\bm{s}^{0}=\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{0}) and is updated recursively as follows:

∀t≥0:𝒔t+1=𝒔t+𝒞(𝒗t+1−𝒔t).\forall t\geq 0\colon\quad\bm{s}^{t+1}=\bm{s}^{t}+\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t+1}-\bm{s}^{t}). (3)

Unlike 𝒞​(𝒗t)𝒞superscript𝒗𝑡\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t}), 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} is not necessarily in the range of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. For example, if 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} uses sparsification, 𝒞​(𝒗t)𝒞superscript𝒗𝑡\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t}) must be sparse, but 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} may not. Accumulating the compressed error of our surrogate allows 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} to “track” 𝒗tsuperscript𝒗𝑡\bm{v}^{t}. Also, since the updates 𝒞​(𝒗t+1−𝒔t)𝒞superscript𝒗𝑡1superscript𝒔𝑡\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t+1}-\bm{s}^{t}) are compressed, we preserve the communication cost of direct compression. Surrogate 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} is updated at both the machine (that is, client or server) sending the information and the one receiving it. Note that 𝒔tsuperscript𝒔𝑡\bm{s}^{t} can be seen as a Markovian compressor, as it depends only on 𝒗tsuperscript𝒗𝑡\bm{v}^{t} and 𝒔t−1superscript𝒔𝑡1\bm{s}^{t-1}.

2.2 Problem setup

Let 𝒉0​n​(𝒙0)=𝒙0subscript𝒉0𝑛subscript𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{h}_{0n}(\bm{x}_{0})=\bm{x}_{0} and 𝒉n​(𝒙)=(𝒉0​n​(𝒙0),…,𝒉K​n​(𝒙K))∈ℝEsubscript𝒉𝑛𝒙subscript𝒉0𝑛subscript𝒙0…subscript𝒉𝐾𝑛subscript𝒙𝐾superscriptℝ𝐸\bm{h}_{n}(\bm{x})=(\bm{h}_{0n}(\bm{x}_{0}),\dots,\bm{h}_{Kn}(\bm{x}_{K}))\in\mathbb{R}^{E} where 𝒉k​n​(𝒙k)∈ℝEksubscript𝒉𝑘𝑛subscript𝒙𝑘superscriptℝsubscript𝐸𝑘\bm{h}_{kn}(\bm{x}_{k})\in\mathbb{R}^{E_{k}} and E=∑k=0KEk𝐸superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾subscript𝐸𝑘E=\sum_{k=0}^{K}E_{k}, for all n𝑛n. Further, let

𝑯k​(𝒙k)=[𝒉k​1​(𝒙k)⋮𝒉k​N​(𝒙k)]∈ℝN×Eksubscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘matrixsubscript𝒉𝑘1subscript𝒙𝑘⋮subscript𝒉𝑘𝑁subscript𝒙𝑘superscriptℝ𝑁subscript𝐸𝑘\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})=\begin{bmatrix}\bm{h}_{k1}(\bm{x}_{k})\\ \vdots\\ \bm{h}_{kN}(\bm{x}_{k})\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times E_{k}}

and

𝑯​(𝒙)≔[𝑯0​(𝒙0),𝑯1​(𝒙1),…,𝑯K​(𝒙K)]∈ℝN×E.≔𝑯𝒙subscript𝑯0subscript𝒙0subscript𝑯1subscript𝒙1…subscript𝑯𝐾subscript𝒙𝐾superscriptℝ𝑁𝐸\bm{H}(\bm{x})\coloneqq[\bm{H}_{0}(\bm{x}_{0}),\bm{H}_{1}(\bm{x}_{1}),\dots,\bm{H}_{K}(\bm{x}_{K})]\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times E}.

Further, we define Φ:ℝN×E↦ℝ:Φmaps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑁𝐸ℝ\Phi\colon\mathbb{R}^{N\times E}\mapsto\mathbb{R} as follows:

f​(𝒙)=1N​∑n=1Nϕn​(𝒉n​(𝒙))≕Φ​(𝑯​(𝒙)).𝑓𝒙1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛subscript𝒉𝑛𝒙≕Φ𝑯𝒙f(\bm{x})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\phi_{n}\left(\bm{h}_{n}(\bm{x})\right)\eqqcolon\Phi\left(\bm{H}(\bm{x})\right).

Throughout most of the paper, we assume that ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n} contains the label of 𝝃nsubscript𝝃𝑛\bm{\xi}_{n} and that ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n} is known by all the clients and the server. This assumption, known as “relaxed protocol” (Liu et al., 2024), is sometimes made in VFL (Hu et al., 2019, Castiglia et al., 2022, 2023) and has applications, for example, in credit score prediction. We also address the case of private labels, proposing a modified version of our method for that setting in Section 3.1.

We assume that f𝑓f has an optimal value f⋆≔min𝒙⁡f​(𝒙)>−∞≔superscript𝑓⋆subscript𝒙𝑓𝒙f^{\star}\coloneqq\min_{\bm{x}}f(\bm{x})>-\infty and make the following assumptions, where ∇∇\nabla denotes not only the gradient of scalar-valued functions but, more generally, the derivative of a (possibly multidimensional) map.

Assumption 1 (Smoothness).

A function h:ℝd↦ℝ:ℎmaps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑ℝh\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R} is L𝐿L-smooth if there exists a positive constant L𝐿L such that

∀𝒙,𝒚∈ℝd:∥∇h(𝒙)−∇h(𝒚)∥≤L∥𝒙−𝒚∥.\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\quad\lVert\nabla h(\bm{x})-\nabla h(\bm{y})\rVert\leq L\lVert\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rVert. (A1)

We assume f𝑓f is Lfsubscript𝐿𝑓L_{f}-smooth and ΦΦ\Phi is LΦsubscript𝐿ΦL_{\Phi}-smooth and let L=max⁡{Lf,LΦ}𝐿subscript𝐿𝑓subscript𝐿ΦL=\max\{L_{f},L_{\Phi}\}.

Assumption 2 (Bounded derivative).

Map 𝐅:ℝp1↦ℝp2×p3:𝐅maps-tosuperscriptℝsubscript𝑝1superscriptℝsubscript𝑝2subscript𝑝3\bm{F}\colon\mathbb{R}^{p_{1}}\mapsto\mathbb{R}^{p_{2}\times p_{3}} has a bounded derivative if there exists a positive constant H𝐻H such that

∀𝒙∈ℝp1:∥∇𝑭(𝒙)∥≤H,\forall\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{p_{1}}\colon\quad\lVert\nabla\bm{F}(\bm{x})\rVert\leq H, (A2)

where ∥∇𝐅​(𝐱)∥delimited-∥∥∇𝐅𝐱\lVert\nabla\bm{F}(\bm{x})\rVert is the Euclidean norm of the third-order tensor ∇𝐅​(𝐱)∇𝐅𝐱\nabla\bm{F}(\bm{x}). We assume (A2) holds for {𝐇k}k=0Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐇𝑘𝑘0𝐾\{\bm{H}_{k}\}_{k=0}^{K}.

Note that, in Assumption 2, we do not assume that our objective function f𝑓f has a bounded gradient. We only require the local representation-extracting maps {𝑯k}subscript𝑯𝑘\{\bm{H}_{k}\} to have a bounded derivative. The same assumption is also made in Castiglia et al. (2022).

3 Proposed method

To solve Problem (1) with a gradient-based method, we need to perform a forward and a backward pass at each step t𝑡t to compute the gradient of our objective function. In VFL, a standard uncompressed algorithm employing a single local update per communication round is mathematically equivalent to gradient descent.777When performing multiple local updates, we lose this mathematical equivalence. In that case, we instead get a parallel (block) coordinate descent method where the simultaneous updates use stale information about the other blocks of variables. This algorithm, which our method recovers if we set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} to be the identity map, is as follows:

  • •

    In the forward pass, each client k𝑘k computes 𝑯k​(𝒙kt)subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}) and sends it to the server, which then computes f​(𝒙t)=Φ​(𝑯​(𝒙t))𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡Φ𝑯superscript𝒙𝑡f(\bm{x}^{t})=\Phi\left(\bm{H}(\bm{x}^{t})\right).

  • •

    In the backward pass, first, the server backpropagates through ΦΦ\Phi, obtaining ∇0Φ​(𝒙0t,{𝑯k​(𝒙kt)}k=1K)=∇0f​(𝒙t)subscript∇0Φsuperscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝐾𝑘1subscript∇0𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡\nabla_{0}\Phi(\bm{x}_{0}^{t},\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\}^{K}_{k=1})=\nabla_{0}f(\bm{x}^{t}) and ∇kΦ​({𝑯k​(𝒙kt)})subscript∇𝑘Φsubscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\nabla_{k}\Phi(\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\}), for all k𝑘k, where ∇ksubscript∇𝑘\nabla_{k} denotes the derivative with respect to block k𝑘k. The former is used to update 𝒙0tsuperscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡\bm{x}_{0}^{t}, while the latter is sent to each client k𝑘k, which uses this derivative to continue backpropagation over its local model, allowing it to compute ∇kf​(𝒙t)subscript∇𝑘𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡\nabla_{k}f(\bm{x}^{t}).

We repeat these steps until convergence. Let us now cover the general case, where 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} may not be the identity map.

Forward pass.

An exact forward pass would require each client k𝑘k to send 𝑯k​(𝒙kt)subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}) to the server, bringing a significant communication overhead. To address this, in our method, the server model does not have as input 𝑯k​(𝒙kt)subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}), but rather a surrogate for it, 𝑮ktsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘𝑡\bm{G}_{k}^{t}, which is initialized as 𝑮k0=𝒞​(𝑯k​(𝒙k0))superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘0𝒞subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘0\bm{G}_{k}^{0}=\mathcal{C}(\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{0})) and is updated as follows, as in (3):

∀k∈[K]:𝑮kt≔𝑮kt−1+𝑪ktwhere𝑪kt≔𝒞(𝑯k(𝒙kt)−𝑮kt−1).\forall k\in[K]:\quad\bm{G}_{k}^{t}\coloneqq\bm{G}_{k}^{t-1}+\bm{C}_{k}^{t}\quad\text{where}\quad\bm{C}_{k}^{t}\coloneqq\mathcal{C}(\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})-\bm{G}_{k}^{t-1}).

This requires keeping 𝑮ktsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘𝑡\bm{G}_{k}^{t}, of size N×Ek𝑁subscript𝐸𝑘N\times E_{k}, in memory at client k𝑘k and at the server. (Note that 𝑮ktsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘𝑡\bm{G}_{k}^{t} is often smaller than the local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}.) The server thus computes the function Φ​(𝒙0t,𝑮1t,…,𝑮Kt)Φsuperscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑮1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑮𝐾𝑡\Phi\left(\bm{x}_{0}^{t},\bm{G}_{1}^{t},\dots,\bm{G}_{K}^{t}\right), which acts as a surrogate for the original objective f​(𝒙t)=Φ​(𝒙0t,𝑯1​(𝒙1t),…,𝑯K​(𝒙Kt))𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡Φsuperscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡subscript𝑯1superscriptsubscript𝒙1𝑡…subscript𝑯𝐾superscriptsubscript𝒙𝐾𝑡f(\bm{x}^{t})=\Phi(\bm{x}_{0}^{t},\bm{H}_{1}(\bm{x}_{1}^{t}),\dots,\bm{H}_{K}(\bm{x}_{K}^{t})), as illustrated in Figure 1.

Backward pass.

The server performs a backward pass over the server model, obtaining ∇0Φ​(𝒙0t,{𝑮kt}k=1K)subscript∇0Φsuperscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘𝑡𝐾𝑘1\nabla_{0}\Phi(\bm{x}_{0}^{t},\{\bm{G}_{k}^{t}\}^{K}_{k=1}), which it uses as a surrogate for ∇0Φ​(𝒙0t,{𝑯k​(𝒙kt)}k=1K)=∇0f​(𝒙t)subscript∇0Φsuperscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝐾𝑘1subscript∇0𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡\nabla_{0}\Phi(\bm{x}_{0}^{t},\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\}^{K}_{k=1})=\nabla_{0}f(\bm{x}^{t}) to update 𝒙0tsuperscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡\bm{x}_{0}^{t}. Similarly, to update each local model 𝒙ktsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\bm{x}_{k}^{t}, for k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K], we want client k𝑘k to have a surrogate for

∇kf​(𝒙t)=∑i,j=1N,Ek[∇kΦ​({𝑯k​(𝒙kt)}k=0K)]i​j​[∇𝑯k​(𝒙kt)]i​j:.subscript∇𝑘𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1𝑁subscript𝐸𝑘subscriptdelimited-[]subscript∇𝑘Φsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝐾𝑘0𝑖𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡:𝑖𝑗absent\nabla_{k}f(\bm{x}^{t})=\sum_{i,j=1}^{N,E_{k}}\left[\nabla_{k}\Phi(\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\}^{K}_{k=0})\right]_{ij}\left[\nabla\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right]_{ij:}.

However, while ∇𝑯k​(𝒙kt)∇subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\nabla\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}) can be computed at each client k𝑘k, the ∇kΦsubscript∇𝑘Φ\nabla_{k}\Phi term cannot, as client k𝑘k does not have access to 𝑯ℓ​(𝒙ℓt)subscript𝑯ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝒙ℓ𝑡\bm{H}_{\ell}(\bm{x}_{\ell}^{t}), for ℓ≠kℓ𝑘\ell\not=k. So, we instead use the following surrogate for ∇kf​(𝒙t)subscript∇𝑘𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡\nabla_{k}f(\bm{x}^{t}):

𝒈kt≔∑i,j=1N,Ek[∇~kt​Φ]i​j​[∇𝑯k​(𝒙kt)]i​j:,≔subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1𝑁subscript𝐸𝑘subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript~∇𝑘𝑡Φ𝑖𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡:𝑖𝑗absent\bm{g}^{t}_{k}\coloneqq\sum_{i,j=1}^{N,E_{k}}\left[\tilde{\nabla}_{k}^{t}\Phi\right]_{ij}\left[\nabla\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right]_{ij:}, (4)

where ∇~kt​Φ≔∇kΦ​(…,𝑮k−1t,𝑯k​(𝒙kt),𝑮k+1t,…)≔superscriptsubscript~∇𝑘𝑡Φsubscript∇𝑘Φ…superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘1𝑡subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘1𝑡…\tilde{\nabla}_{k}^{t}\Phi\coloneqq\nabla_{k}\Phi(...,\bm{G}_{k-1}^{t},\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}),\bm{G}_{k+1}^{t},...). Since the server does not hold 𝑯k​(𝒙kt)subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}), it cannot compute ∇~kt​Φsuperscriptsubscript~∇𝑘𝑡Φ\tilde{\nabla}_{k}^{t}\Phi. Thus, the server broadcasts {𝑪kt}k=0Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑪𝑘𝑡𝑘0𝐾\{\bm{C}_{k}^{t}\}_{k=0}^{K}, so that each client k𝑘k, which does hold 𝑯k​(𝒙kt)subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}), can compute {𝑮ℓt}ℓ≠ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑮ℓ𝑡ℓ𝑘\{\bm{G}_{\ell}^{t}\}_{\ell\not=k} and use it to perform a forward and a backward pass over the server model locally, obtaining ∇~kt​Φsuperscriptsubscript~∇𝑘𝑡Φ\tilde{\nabla}_{k}^{t}\Phi. Thus, while the forward pass only requires the error feedback module at each client k𝑘k to hold the estimate 𝑮ktsubscriptsuperscript𝑮𝑡𝑘\bm{G}^{t}_{k}, when we account for the backward pass too, each machine k∈{0,1,…,K}𝑘01…𝐾k\in\{0,1,\dots,K\} must hold {𝑮ℓt}ℓ=0Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑮ℓ𝑡ℓ0𝐾\{\bm{G}_{\ell}^{t}\}_{\ell=0}^{K}. We write our update as:

𝒙t+1=𝒙t−η​𝒈twhere𝒈t≔(𝒈0t,…,𝒈Kt)formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒙𝑡1superscript𝒙𝑡𝜂superscript𝒈𝑡where≔superscript𝒈𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡0…subscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡𝐾\bm{x}^{t+1}=\bm{x}^{t}-\eta\bm{g}^{t}\quad\text{where}\quad\bm{g}^{t}\coloneqq(\bm{g}^{t}_{0},\dots,\bm{g}^{t}_{K})

and η𝜂\eta is the stepsize.

Mini-batch.

For the sake of computation efficiency, we further allow for the use of mini-batch approximations of the objective. Without compression, or with direct compression, the use of mini-batches allows client k𝑘k to send only the entries of 𝑯k​(𝒙k)subscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}) corresponding to mini-batch ℬ⊆[N]ℬdelimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{B}\subseteq[N], of size B𝐵B, denoted by 𝑯k​ℬ​(𝒙k)∈ℝB×Eksubscript𝑯𝑘ℬsubscript𝒙𝑘superscriptℝ𝐵subscript𝐸𝑘\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}}(\bm{x}_{k})\in\mathbb{R}^{B\times E_{k}}, instead of 𝑯k​(𝒙k)∈ℝN×Eksubscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘superscriptℝ𝑁subscript𝐸𝑘\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times E_{k}}. Yet, our method provides all machines with an estimate for all the entries of {𝑯k​(𝒙k)}subscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})\} at all times, the error feedback states {𝑮k}subscript𝑮𝑘\{\bm{G}_{k}\}. Therefore, our communications, needed to update 𝑮ksubscript𝑮𝑘\bm{G}_{k}, may not depend on N𝑁N and B𝐵B at all. This is determined by our choice of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}.

Our mini-batch surrogates depend on the entries of 𝑯k​(𝒙k)subscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}) and 𝑮ksubscript𝑮𝑘\bm{G}_{k} corresponding to ℬℬ\mathcal{B}, 𝑯k​ℬ​(𝒙k)subscript𝑯𝑘ℬsubscript𝒙𝑘\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}}(\bm{x}_{k}), and 𝑮k​ℬsubscript𝑮𝑘ℬ\bm{G}_{k\mathcal{B}}. (Note that 𝑯0​ℬ​(𝒙0)=𝑯0​(𝒙0)subscript𝑯0ℬsubscript𝒙0subscript𝑯0subscript𝒙0\bm{H}_{0\mathcal{B}}(\bm{x}_{0})=\bm{H}_{0}(\bm{x}_{0}) and 𝑮0​ℬt=𝑮0tsuperscriptsubscript𝑮0ℬ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑮0𝑡\bm{G}_{0\mathcal{B}}^{t}=\bm{G}_{0}^{t}.) Thus, we approximate the partial derivative of the mini-batch function fℬ​(𝒙)=Φℬ​({𝑯k​ℬ​(𝒙k)})=1B​∑n∈ℬϕn​(𝒉n​(𝒙))subscript𝑓ℬ𝒙subscriptΦℬsubscript𝑯𝑘ℬsubscript𝒙𝑘1𝐵subscript𝑛ℬsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛subscript𝒉𝑛𝒙f_{\mathcal{B}}(\bm{x})=\Phi_{\mathcal{B}}(\{\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}}(\bm{x}_{k})\})=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{B}}\phi_{n}\left(\bm{h}_{n}(\bm{x})\right) with respect to 𝒙ksubscript𝒙𝑘\bm{x}_{k} by:

𝒈~kt≔∑i∈ℬt∑j=1Ek[∇~kt​Φℬt]i​j​[∇𝑯k​ℬt​(𝒙kt)]i​j:,≔subscriptsuperscript~𝒈𝑡𝑘subscript𝑖superscriptℬ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐸𝑘subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript~∇𝑘𝑡subscriptΦsuperscriptℬ𝑡𝑖𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptℬ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡:𝑖𝑗absent\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}_{k}\coloneqq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}^{t}}\sum_{j=1}^{E_{k}}\left[\tilde{\nabla}_{k}^{t}\Phi_{\mathcal{B}^{t}}\right]_{ij}\left[\nabla\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}^{t}}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right]_{ij:},

where ∇~kt​Φℬt≔∇kΦℬt​(…,𝑮k−1,ℬtt,𝑯k​ℬt​(𝒙kt),𝑮k+1,ℬtt,…)≔superscriptsubscript~∇𝑘𝑡subscriptΦsuperscriptℬ𝑡subscript∇𝑘subscriptΦsuperscriptℬ𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘1superscriptℬ𝑡𝑡subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptℬ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘1superscriptℬ𝑡𝑡…\tilde{\nabla}_{k}^{t}\Phi_{\mathcal{B}^{t}}\coloneqq\nabla_{k}\Phi_{\mathcal{B}^{t}}(...,\bm{G}_{k-1,\mathcal{B}^{t}}^{t},\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}^{t}}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}),\bm{G}_{k+1,\mathcal{B}^{t}}^{t},...). We write the mini-batch version of the update as:

𝒙t+1=𝒙t−η​𝒈~twhere𝒈~t≔(𝒈~0t,…,𝒈~Kt).formulae-sequencesuperscript𝒙𝑡1superscript𝒙𝑡𝜂superscript~𝒈𝑡where≔superscript~𝒈𝑡subscriptsuperscript~𝒈𝑡0…subscriptsuperscript~𝒈𝑡𝐾\bm{x}^{t+1}=\bm{x}^{t}-\eta\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}\quad\text{where}\quad\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}\coloneqq\left(\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}_{0},\dots,\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}_{K}\right).

We now describe our method, which we summarize in Algorithm 1.

  • •

    Initialization: We initialize our model parameters as 𝒙0superscript𝒙0\bm{x}^{0}. Each machine k∈{0,1,…,K}𝑘01…𝐾k\in\{0,1,\dots,K\} must hold 𝒙k0superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘0\bm{x}_{k}^{0} and our compression estimates {𝑮k0=𝒞​(𝑯k​(𝒙k0))}k=0Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘0𝒞subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘0𝑘0𝐾\{\bm{G}_{k}^{0}=\mathcal{C}(\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{0}))\}_{k=0}^{K}.

  • •

    Model parameters update: In parallel, all machines k∈{0,1,…,K}𝑘01…𝐾k\in\{0,1,\dots,K\} take a (stochastic) coordinate descent step with respect to their local surrogate objective, updating 𝒙kt+1=𝒙kt−η​𝒈~ktsubscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑡1𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒙𝑡𝑘𝜂subscriptsuperscript~𝒈𝑡𝑘\bm{x}^{t+1}_{k}=\bm{x}^{t}_{k}-\eta\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}_{k} based on a shared batch ℬtsuperscriptℬ𝑡\mathcal{B}^{t}, sampled locally at each client following a shared seed.

  • •

    Compressed communications: All clients k∈[K]𝑘delimited-[]𝐾k\in[K] compute 𝑪kt+1superscriptsubscript𝑪𝑘𝑡1\bm{C}_{k}^{t+1} and send it to the server, who broadcasts {𝑪kt+1}superscriptsubscript𝑪𝑘𝑡1\{\bm{C}_{k}^{t+1}\}.

  • •

    Compression estimates update: Lastly, all machines k∈{0,1,…,K}𝑘01…𝐾k\in\{0,1,\dots,K\} use the compressed error feedback {𝑪kt+1}superscriptsubscript𝑪𝑘𝑡1\{\bm{C}_{k}^{t+1}\} to update their (matching) compression estimates {𝑮kt}superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘𝑡\{\bm{G}_{k}^{t}\}.

Note that, in the absence of compression (that is, if 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is the identity operator), each client k𝑘k must send 𝑪kt+1superscriptsubscript𝑪𝑘𝑡1\bm{C}_{k}^{t+1}, of size N×Ek𝑁subscript𝐸𝑘N\times E_{k}, at each iteration. Further, the server must broadcast {𝑪kt+1}k=0Ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑪𝑘𝑡1𝑘0𝐾\{\bm{C}_{k}^{t+1}\}_{k=0}^{K}. Thus, the total communication complexity of EFVFL in the absence of compression is 𝒪​(N⋅E⋅T)𝒪⋅𝑁𝐸𝑇\mathcal{O}(N\cdot E\cdot T). When compression is used, N⋅E⋅𝑁𝐸N\cdot E is replaced by some smaller amount which depends on the compression mechanism. For example, for top-k𝑘k sparsification (defined in Section 5), the communication complexity is reduced to 𝒪​(k⋅T)𝒪⋅𝑘𝑇\mathcal{O}(k\cdot T).

In Algorithm 1, we formulate our method in a general setting which allows for the compression of both {𝑯k​(𝒙k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K} and 𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{x}_{0}. This setting is covered by our analysis in Section 4. However, in general, the bottleneck lies in the uplink (client-to-server) communications, rather than the server broadcasting (Haddadpour et al., 2021). Therefore, our experiments in Section 5 focus on the compression of {𝑯k​(𝒙k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K}, rather than 𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{x}_{0}.

3.1 Adapting our method for handling private labels

In this section, we propose an adaptation of EFVFL to allow for private labels. That is, we remove the assumption that all clients hold ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n}, which contains the label of 𝝃nsubscript𝝃𝑛\bm{\xi}_{n}. Instead, only the server holds the labels. Further, in this adaptation, the parameters of the server model, 𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{x}_{0}, are not shared with the clients either.

Note that, without holding ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n}, the clients cannot perform the entire forward pass locally. Instead, in this setting, the forward and backward pass over ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n} take place at the server, while the forward and backward pass over 𝑯k​(𝒙k)subscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}) takes place at client k𝑘k. More precisely, in the forward pass, each client k𝑘k sends 𝑪ksubscript𝑪𝑘\bm{C}_{k} to the server, who holds 𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{x}_{0} and the labels, and can thus compute the loss. Then, for the backward pass, the server backpropagates over its model and sends only the derivative of the loss function with respect to 𝑮ksubscript𝑮𝑘\bm{G}_{k} to each client k𝑘k. This requires replacing our surrogate of ∇kf​(𝒙t)subscript∇𝑘𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡\nabla_{k}f(\bm{x}^{t}) in (4), which uses the exact local representation 𝑯k​(𝒙k)subscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}) at each client, by one based on our error feedback surrogates:

∇kt≔∑i,j=1N,Ek[∇kΦ​(𝑯0​(𝒙0t),{𝑮jt}j=1K)]i​j​[∇𝑯k​(𝒙kt)]i​j:.≔subscriptsuperscriptbold-∇𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖𝑗1𝑁subscript𝐸𝑘subscriptdelimited-[]subscript∇𝑘Φsubscript𝑯0superscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝑗𝑡𝐾𝑗1𝑖𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡:𝑖𝑗absent\bm{\nabla}^{t}_{k}\coloneqq\sum_{i,j=1}^{N,E_{k}}\left[\nabla_{k}\Phi\left(\bm{H}_{0}(\bm{x}_{0}^{t}),\{\bm{G}_{j}^{t}\}^{K}_{j=1}\right)\right]_{ij}\left[\nabla\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right]_{ij:}. (5)

Note that we do not backpropagate through the error-feedback update.

More generally, we use the following (possibly) mini-batch update vector:

∇~kt≔∑i∈ℬt∑j=1Ek[∇kΦℬt​(𝑯0​ℬt​(𝒙0t),{𝑮j​ℬtt}j=1K)]i​j​[∇𝑯k​ℬt​(𝒙kt)]i​j:.≔subscriptsuperscript~bold-∇𝑡𝑘subscript𝑖superscriptℬ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝐸𝑘subscriptdelimited-[]subscript∇𝑘subscriptΦsuperscriptℬ𝑡subscript𝑯0superscriptℬ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒙0𝑡subscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑮𝑗superscriptℬ𝑡𝑡𝐾𝑗1𝑖𝑗subscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptℬ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡:𝑖𝑗absent\tilde{\bm{\nabla}}^{t}_{k}\coloneqq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}^{t}}\sum_{j=1}^{E_{k}}\left[\nabla_{k}\Phi_{\mathcal{B}^{t}}\left(\bm{H}_{0\mathcal{B}^{t}}(\bm{x}_{0}^{t}),\{\bm{G}_{j\mathcal{B}^{t}}^{t}\}^{K}_{j=1}\right)\right]_{ij}\left[\nabla\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}^{t}}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right]_{ij:}.

We summarize the adaption of the EFVFL method to the private labels setting in Algorithm 2.

Allowing for private labels broadens the range of applications for our method, since many VFL applications require not only private features, but also private labels, rendering any method requiring public labels inapplicable. However, as we will see in Section 5.2, using surrogate (5) instead of (4) can slow down convergence. Further, unlike Algorithm 1, which can be easily extendable to allow for multiple local updates at the clients between rounds of communication, Algorithm 2 works only for a single local update. This is because, for an VFL algorithm to perform multiple local updates, ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n} and 𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{x}_{0} must be available at the clients, so that the forward and backward passes over the server model and the loss function can be performed locally after each update.

4 Convergence guarantees

In this section, we provide convergence guarantees for EFVFL. We present our results for Algorithm 1 only, rather then stating them again for Algorithm 2, since they exhibit only a minor difference in Lemma 1 and in main theorem, where the constant K𝐾K is replaced with K+1𝐾1K+1. We defer the details to Appendix A.

First, let us define the following sigma-algebra

ℱt≔σ​(𝑮0,𝒙1,𝑮1,…,𝒙t,𝑮t),≔subscriptℱ𝑡𝜎superscript𝑮0superscript𝒙1superscript𝑮1…superscript𝒙𝑡superscript𝑮𝑡\mathcal{F}_{t}\coloneqq\sigma(\bm{G}^{0},\bm{x}^{1},\bm{G}^{1},\dots,\bm{x}^{t},\bm{G}^{t}),

where 𝑮t≔{𝑮0t,…,𝑮Kt}≔superscript𝑮𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑮𝑡0…subscriptsuperscript𝑮𝑡𝐾\bm{G}^{t}\coloneqq\{\bm{G}^{t}_{0},\dots,\bm{G}^{t}_{K}\}. For the sake of conciseness, we further let 𝔼ℱsubscript𝔼ℱ\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{F}} denote the conditional expectation 𝔼[⋅∣ℱ]\mathbb{E}[\cdot\mid\mathcal{F}] with sigma-algebra ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. We use the following assumptions on our stochastic update vector 𝒈~tsuperscript~𝒈𝑡\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t} and the use of mini-batches.

Assumption 3 (Unbiased).

We assume that our stochastic update vector is unbiased:

∀(𝒙,t)∈ℝd×{0,1,…,T−1}:𝔼ℱt[𝒈~t]=𝒈t.\forall(\bm{x},t)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\{0,1,\dots,T-1\}\colon\quad\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{F}_{t}}\left[\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}\right]=\bm{g}^{t}. (A3)
Assumption 4 (Bounded variance).

We assume that there exists a constant σ≥0𝜎0\sigma\geq 0 such that

∀(𝒙,t)∈ℝd×{0,1,…,T−1}:𝔼ℱt∥𝒈~t−𝒈t∥2≤σ2B.\forall(\bm{x},t)\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\{0,1,\dots,T-1\}\colon\quad\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{F}_{t}}\lVert\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}-\bm{g}^{t}\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{\sigma^{2}}{B}. (A4)

We now present Lemma 1 and Lemma 2, which we will use to prove our main theorems. We let Dt≔∑k=0K∥𝑮kt−𝑯k​(𝒙kt)∥2≔superscript𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘𝑡subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡2D^{t}\coloneqq\sum_{k=0}^{K}\left\lVert\bm{G}_{k}^{t}-\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right\rVert^{2} denote the total distortion (caused by compression) at time t𝑡t.

If ΦΦ\Phi is L𝐿L-smooth (A1) and {𝐇k}subscript𝐇𝑘\{\bm{H}_{k}\} have bounded derivatives (A2), then, for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0,

∥𝒈t−∇f​(𝒙t)∥2≤K​H2​L2​Dt.superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝒈𝑡∇𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡2𝐾superscript𝐻2superscript𝐿2superscript𝐷𝑡\lVert\bm{g}^{t}-\nabla f(\bm{x}^{t})\rVert^{2}\leq KH^{2}L^{2}D^{t}. (6)
Proof.

4.1 Nonconvex setting

We now present our main convergence result for EFVFL.

Theorem 1.

Let {𝐱t}superscript𝐱𝑡\{\bm{x}^{t}\} be a sequence generated by Algorithm 1, 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} be a contractive compressor (2), and f⋆>−∞superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star}>-\infty. If (A1) to (A4) hold, then, for 0<η≤1/(ρα​1​L+L)0𝜂1subscript𝜌𝛼1𝐿𝐿0<\eta\leq 1/(\sqrt{\rho_{\alpha 1}}L+L):

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​∥∇f​(𝒙t)∥2≤2​Δη​T+(1+η​L​ρα​1)​η​L​σ2B+ρα​2​𝔼​D0T,1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡22Δ𝜂𝑇1𝜂𝐿subscript𝜌𝛼1𝜂𝐿superscript𝜎2𝐵subscript𝜌𝛼2𝔼superscript𝐷0𝑇\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{t})\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{2\Delta}{\eta T}+\left(1+\eta L\rho_{\alpha 1}\right)\frac{\eta L\sigma^{2}}{B}+\rho_{\alpha 2}\frac{\mathbb{E}D^{0}}{T}, (8)

where the expectation is over the randomness in 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} and in {ℬt}subscriptℬ𝑡\{\mathcal{B}_{t}\}, Δ≔f​(𝛉0)−f⋆≔Δ𝑓superscript𝛉0superscript𝑓⋆\Delta\coloneqq f\left(\bm{\theta}^{0}\right)-f^{\star}, and

ρα​1≔K​H4​(1+1−αα−1)2andρα​2≔K​H2​L21−1−α.formulae-sequence≔subscript𝜌𝛼1𝐾superscript𝐻4superscript11𝛼𝛼12and≔subscript𝜌𝛼2𝐾superscript𝐻2superscript𝐿211𝛼\rho_{\alpha 1}\coloneqq KH^{4}\left(\frac{1+\sqrt{1-\alpha}}{\alpha}-1\right)^{2}\quad\text{and}\quad\rho_{\alpha 2}\coloneqq\frac{KH^{2}L^{2}}{1-\sqrt{1-\alpha}}.
Proof.

See Appendix C.1. ∎

If the batch size is large enough, B=Ω​(σ2/ε)𝐵Ωsuperscript𝜎2𝜀B=\Omega(\sigma^{2}/\varepsilon), the iteration complexity to reach 1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​∥∇f​(𝜽t)∥2≤ε1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝜽𝑡2𝜀\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\left\lVert\nabla f\left(\bm{\theta}^{t}\right)\right\rVert^{2}\leq\varepsilon matches the 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T) rate of the centralized, uncompressed setting. Also, in the absence of compression (α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 and Dt=0superscript𝐷𝑡0D^{t}=0), we recover that, for η∈(0,1/L]𝜂01𝐿\eta\in(0,1/L], we can output an 𝒙outsuperscript𝒙out\bm{x}^{\text{out}} such that 𝔼​∥∇f​(𝒙out)∥2≤2​Δη​T+η​L​σ2B𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝒙out22Δ𝜂𝑇𝜂𝐿superscript𝜎2𝐵\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{\text{out}})\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{2\Delta}{\eta T}+\frac{\eta L\sigma^{2}}{B}. If we are also in the full-batch case (σ=0𝜎0\sigma=0), we recover the gradient descent bound exactly: 𝔼​∥∇f​(𝒙out)∥2≤2​Δη​T𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝒙out22Δ𝜂𝑇\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{\text{out}})\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{2\Delta}{\eta T}.

Our results improve over the prior state-of-the-art compressed vertical FL (CVFL) (Castiglia et al., 2022), whose convergence results for a fixed stepsize is presented below:

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​∥∇f​(𝒙t)∥2≤4​Δη​T+𝒪​(η​L​σ2B)+𝒪​(1T​∑t=0T−1Ddt).1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡24Δ𝜂𝑇𝒪𝜂𝐿superscript𝜎2𝐵𝒪1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑑𝑡\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{t})\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{4\Delta}{\eta T}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\eta L\sigma^{2}}{B}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}D_{d}^{t}\right).

Note how, even for full-batch updates, the upper bound above does not go to zero as T→∞→𝑇T\to\infty unless Ddt→0→superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑑𝑡0D_{d}^{t}\to 0, where Ddtsuperscriptsubscript𝐷𝑑𝑡D_{d}^{t} is the distortion resulting from direct compression Ddt=∑k=0K∥𝒞​(𝑯k​(𝒙kt))−𝑯k​(𝒙kt)∥2superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑑𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒞subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡2D_{d}^{t}=\sum_{k=0}^{K}\left\lVert\mathcal{C}(\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}))-\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right\rVert^{2}. That is, to achieve 1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​∥∇f​(𝒙t)∥2→0→1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡20\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{t})\rVert^{2}\to 0, CVFL requires a vanishing compression error, which necessitates that α→1→𝛼1\alpha\to 1. This means that, despite reducing the total amount communications across the training, CVFL does not reduce the maximum amount of communications per round. In contrast, by allowing for nonvanishing compression, EFVFL ensures small communication cost at every round.

4.2 Under the PL inequality

In this section, we establish the linear convergence of EFVFL under the PL inequality (Polyak, 1963).

Assumption 5 (PL inequality).

We assume that there exists a positive constant μ𝜇\mu such that

∀𝒙∈ℝd:∥∇f(𝒙)∥2≥2μ(f(𝒙)−f⋆).\forall\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\quad\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}\geq 2\mu(f(\bm{x})-f^{\star}). (A5)

We resort to the following Lyapunov function to show linear convergence:

Vt≔𝔼​f​(𝒙t)−f⋆+c​𝔼​Dt,≔subscript𝑉𝑡𝔼𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡superscript𝑓⋆𝑐𝔼superscript𝐷𝑡V_{t}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}f(\bm{x}^{t})-f^{\star}+c\mathbb{E}D^{t}, (9)

where c𝑐c is a positive constant. We now present Theorem 2.

Theorem 2.

Let {𝐱t}superscript𝐱𝑡\{\bm{x}^{t}\} be a sequence generated by Algorithm 1, 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} be a contractive compressor (2), and f⋆>−∞superscript𝑓⋆f^{\star}>-\infty. If (A1) to (A5) hold, then, for η𝜂\eta such that η2​L2​(1−μ/L)+η​μ≤α2superscript𝜂2superscript𝐿21𝜇𝐿𝜂𝜇superscript𝛼2\eta^{2}L^{2}\left(1-\mu/L\right)+\eta\mu\leq\alpha^{2}, we have:

VT≤(1−η​μ)T​V0+𝒪​(η​σ2B).subscript𝑉𝑇superscript1𝜂𝜇𝑇subscript𝑉0𝒪𝜂superscript𝜎2𝐵V_{T}\leq(1-\eta\mu)^{T}V_{0}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\eta\sigma^{2}}{B}\right).
Proof.

See Appendix C.2. ∎

Since μ≤L𝜇𝐿\mu\leq L, we have that η∈(0,1/L)𝜂01𝐿\eta\in(0,1/L) implies that 1−η​μ∈(0,1)1𝜂𝜇011-\eta\mu\in(0,1). Hence, EFVFL converges linearly to a 𝒪​(σ2)𝒪superscript𝜎2\mathcal{O}(\sigma^{2}) neighborhood around the global optimum.

5 Experiments

We compare EFVFL with two baselines: (1) standard VFL (SVFL), which corresponds to the method in Liu et al. (2022) and is mathematically equivalent to stochastic gradient descent when a single local update is used, and (2) CVFL (Castiglia et al., 2022), which recovers SVFL when an identity compressor is used (that is, without employing compression). All of our results correspond to the mean and standard deviation for five different seeds. We employ two popular compressors in our experiments.

  • •

    Top-k𝑘k sparsification (Alistarh et al., 2018, Stich et al., 2018) is a map topk:ℝd↦ℝd:subscripttop𝑘maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\text{top}_{k}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R}^{d} defined as

    topk​(𝒗)≔𝒗⊙𝒖​(𝒗),≔subscripttop𝑘𝒗direct-product𝒗𝒖𝒗\text{top}_{k}(\bm{v})\coloneqq\bm{v}\odot\bm{u}(\bm{v}),

    where ⊙direct-product\odot denotes the Hadamard product and 𝒖​(𝒗)𝒖𝒗\bm{u}(\bm{v}) is such that its entry i𝑖i is 1 if visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} is one of the k𝑘k largest entries of 𝒗𝒗\bm{v} in absolute value and 0 otherwise. We have that (2) holds for α=k/d𝛼𝑘𝑑\alpha=k/d.

  • •

    Stochastic quantization (Alistarh et al., 2017) is a map qsgds:ℝd↦ℝd:subscriptqsgd𝑠maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\text{qsgd}_{s}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R}^{d}, with s>1𝑠1s>1 quantization levels defined as

    qsgds​(𝒗)≔∥𝒗∥⋅sign​(𝒗)s​τ⋅⌊s​|𝒗|∥𝒗∥+ξ⌋,≔subscriptqsgd𝑠𝒗⋅⋅delimited-∥∥𝒗sign𝒗𝑠𝜏𝑠𝒗delimited-∥∥𝒗𝜉\text{qsgd}_{s}(\bm{v})\coloneqq\frac{\lVert\bm{v}\rVert\cdot\text{sign}(\bm{v})}{s\tau}\cdot\left\lfloor s\frac{\lvert\bm{v}\rvert}{\lVert\bm{v}\rVert}+\xi\right\rfloor,

    where τ=1+min⁡{d/s2,d/s}𝜏1𝑑superscript𝑠2𝑑𝑠\tau=1+\min\{d/s^{2},\sqrt{d}/s\} and ξ∼𝒰​([0,1]d)similar-to𝜉𝒰superscript01𝑑\xi\sim\mathcal{U}([0,1]^{d}), where 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} denotes the uniform distribution. In practice, we are interested in values of s𝑠s such that s=2b𝑠superscript2𝑏s=2^{b}, where b𝑏b is the number of bits. We have that (2) holds for α=1/τ𝛼1𝜏\alpha=1/\tau.

For the sake of the comparison with CVFL, we employ compressors 𝒞=𝒞2∘𝒞1𝒞subscript𝒞2subscript𝒞1\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{C}_{2}\circ\mathcal{C}_{1}, where 𝒞2subscript𝒞2\mathcal{C}_{2} is either topk​(𝒗)subscripttop𝑘𝒗\text{top}_{k}(\bm{v}) or qsgdssubscriptqsgd𝑠\text{qsgd}_{s} and 𝒞1subscript𝒞1\mathcal{C}_{1} selects the rows in ℬtsuperscriptℬ𝑡\mathcal{B}^{t}, similarly to CVFL. Further, as explained in Section 3, our experiments focus on the compression of {𝑯k​(𝒙k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑯𝑘subscript𝒙𝑘𝑘1𝐾\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K}, and not 𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{x}_{0}.

5.1 Comparison with SVFL and CVFL

MNIST.

We train a shallow neural network (one hidden layer) on the MNIST digit recognition dataset (LeCun et al., 1998). The 28×28282828\times 28 images in the original dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} are split into four local datasets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} of 14×14141414\times 14 images, its quadrants (K=4𝐾4K=4). The local models 𝒉k​nsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑛\bm{h}_{kn} are maps 𝒗↦sigmoid​(𝑾k​1​𝒗)maps-to𝒗sigmoidsubscript𝑾𝑘1𝒗\bm{v}\mapsto\text{sigmoid}(\bm{W}_{k1}\bm{v}), with 𝑾k​1∈ℝ16×196subscript𝑾𝑘1superscriptℝ16196\bm{W}_{k1}\in\mathbb{R}^{16\times 196}, and the server model is (𝒗1,…,𝒗4)↦𝑾2​(∑k=14𝒗k)maps-tosubscript𝒗1…subscript𝒗4subscript𝑾2superscriptsubscript𝑘14subscript𝒗𝑘(\bm{v}_{1},\dots,\bm{v}_{4})\mapsto\bm{W}_{2}(\sum_{k=1}^{4}\bm{v}_{k}), with 𝑾2∈ℝ10×16subscript𝑾2superscriptℝ1016\bm{W}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 16}. We use cross-entropy loss. All three VFL optimizers use stepsize η=1𝜂1\eta=1 and full-batch gradients. In Figure 2, we present the results for when EFVFL and CVFL employ topksubscripttop𝑘\text{top}_{k}, keeping 10%percent1010\%, 1%percent11\%, and 0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the entries, and when they employ qsgdssubscriptqsgd𝑠\text{qsgd}_{s}, sending b∈{5,2,1}𝑏521b\in\{5,2,1\} bits per entry, instead of the uncompressed b=32𝑏32b=32. In both figures, we see that EFVFL outperforms SVFL and CVFL in communication efficiency. In terms of results per epoch, EFVFL significantly outperforms CVFL and, for a sufficiently large k𝑘k (for topksubscripttop𝑘\text{top}_{k}) or b𝑏b (for qsgdssubscriptqsgd𝑠\text{qsgd}_{s}) EFVFL achieves a similar performance to SVFL. As predicted in Section 4, the train gradient squared norm during training goes to zero for EFVFL, as it does for SVFL, but not for CVFL.

ModelNet10.

We train a multi-view convolutional neural network (MVCNN) (Su et al., 2015) on ModelNet10 (Wu et al., 2015), a dataset of three-dimensional CAD models. We use a preprocessed version of ModelNet10, where each sample is represented by 12 two-dimensional views. We assign a view per client (K=12𝐾12K=12). For all three VFL optimizers, we use a batch size B=128𝐵128B=128, a stepsize η=0.004𝜂0.004\eta=0.004, and a weight decay of 0.01. In Figure 3, we present the results for when EFVFL and CVFL employ topksubscripttop𝑘\text{top}_{k}, keeping 20%percent2020\%, 2%percent22\%, and 0.2%percent0.20.2\% of the entries, and when they employ qsgdssubscriptqsgd𝑠\text{qsgd}_{s}, with b∈{8,4,2}𝑏842b\in\{8,4,2\}. We plot the train loss with respect to the number of epochs and the test accuracy with respect to the communication cost. We observe that, for EFVFL, the training loss decreases more rapidly than for CVFL. Further, if the compression is not excessively aggressive, EFVFL performs similarly to SVFL. In terms of communication efficiency, EFVFL outperforms both SVFL and CVFL.

CIFAR-10.

We train a model based on a residual neural network, ResNet18 (He et al., 2016), on CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009). More precisely, we divide each image into four quadrants and allocate one quadrant to each client (K=4𝐾4K=4), with each client using a ResNet18 model as its local model. The server model is a multilayer perceptron with three layers. All three VFL optimizers use a batch size B=128𝐵128B=128, a stepsize η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01, and a weight decay of 0.01. In Figure 4, we present the results for when EFVFL and CVFL employ topksubscripttop𝑘\text{top}_{k}, keeping 10%percent1010\%, 1%percent11\%, and 0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the entries, and when they employ qsgdssubscriptqsgd𝑠\text{qsgd}_{s}, with b∈{4,2,1}𝑏421b\in\{4,2,1\}. We plot the train loss with respect to the number of epochs and the test accuracy with respect to the communication cost. Regarding the results with respect to the number of epochs, EFVFL achieves a similar performance to that of SVFL, significantly outperforming CVFL. In terms of communication efficiency, EFVFL outperforms both SVFL and CVFL.

5.2 Performance under private labels

In this section, we run experiments on the adaption of EFVFL to handle private labels, proposed in Section 3.1.

In Castiglia et al. (2022), the authors assume that the labels are available at all clients and do not propose an adaptation of CVFL to deal with private labels. Yet, to get a baseline for a compressed VFL method allowing for label privacy, we adapt CVFL in a similar manner to how we adapt EFVFL (that is, sending back the derivative from the server to the clients, instead of ϕnsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛\phi_{n} and 𝒙0subscript𝒙0\bm{x}_{0}, and without backpropagating through the compression operator).

We run an experiment on MNIST, training the same shallow neural network as in model as in Section 5.1, with all the same settings, except for the use of batch size B=1024𝐵1024B=1024. Further, we train another ResNet18-based model, now with a linear server model (a single layer), on CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009). For all the optimizers, we use an initial stepsize of η=0.01𝜂0.01\eta=0.01 and a cosine annealing scheduler with a minimum stepsize of 1/10011001/100 the initial value and use a batch size B=128𝐵128B=128 and a weight decay of 0.010.010.01. The compressed-communication methods employ topksubscripttop𝑘\text{top}_{k}, keeping 5%percent55\% of the entries.

In Figure 5, we observe that, although the modified EFVFL for handling private labels converges noticeably slower than the original method, it still performs effectively. For both the MNIST experiment and the CIFAR-100 experiment, we see that, while adapting CVFL to handle private labels leads to a severe drop in performance, EFVFL slows down much less noticeably. In fact, for the MNIST experiment, EFVFL with private labels still outperforms CVFL, even with public labels.

5.3 Performance under multiple local updates

As mentioned earlier, some VFL works employ Q>1𝑄1Q>1 local updates per round (Liu et al., 2022), using stale information from the other machines. We now show that, although our analysis focuses on the case where each client performs a single local update at each round of communications (that is, Q=1𝑄1Q=1), EFVFL performs well in the Q>1𝑄1Q>1 case too. In particular, to study the performance of EFVFL when carrying out multiple local updates, we train an MVCNN on ModelNet10 and a ResNet18 on CIFAR-10, on the same setups as in Section 5.1.

For ModelNet10, all three VFL optimizers use a batch size B=128𝐵128B=128, a stepsize η=0.004𝜂0.004\eta=0.004, and a weight decay of 0.01. Further, we use a learning rate scheduler, halving the learning rate at epochs 50 and 75. The results are presented in Figure 6(a) and Figure 6(b). For CIFAR-10, all three VFL optimizers use a batch size B=128𝐵128B=128, a stepsize η=0.0025𝜂0.0025\eta=0.0025, and a weight decay of 0.01. Further, we use a learning rate scheduler, halving the learning rate at epochs 40, 60, and 80. The results are presented in Figure 6(c) and Figure 6(d).

For both ModelNet10 and CIFAR-10, we see that, similarly to the Q=1𝑄1Q=1 case, our method outperforms SVFL and CVFL in communication efficiency. In terms of results per epoch, EFVFL performs similarly to SVFL and significantly better than CVFL. Interestingly, for the CIFAR-10 task, EFVFL even outperforms SVFL with respect to the number of epochs. We suspect this may be due to the fact that compression helps to mitigate the overly greedy nature of the parallel updates based on stale information.

6 Conclusions

In this work, we proposed EFVFL, a method for compressed vertical federated learning. Our method leverages an error feedback mechanism to achieve a 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/T) convergence rate, improving upon the state-of-the-art rate of 𝒪​(1/T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}). Numerical experiments further demonstrate the faster convergence of our method. We further show that, under the PL inequality, our method converges linearly and introduce a modification of EFVFL supporting the use of private labels. In the future, it would be interesting to study the use of error feedback based compression methods for VFL in the fully-decentralized and semi-decentralized settings, as well as combining it with privacy mechanisms, such as differential privacy.

Appendix A Preliminaries

If a function is L𝐿L-smooth (A1), then the following quadratic upper bound holds:

∀𝒙,𝒚∈ℝd:f(𝒚)≤f(𝒙)+∇f(𝒙)⊤(𝒚−𝒙)+L2∥𝒙−𝒚∥2.\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\quad f(\bm{y})\leq f(\bm{x})+\nabla f(\bm{x})^{\top}(\bm{y}-\bm{x})+\frac{L}{2}\lVert\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rVert^{2}. (10)

It follows from Assumption (2) that the following inequality holds:

∥𝑯k​(𝒙)−𝑯k​(𝒚)∥≤H​∥𝒙−𝒚∥,∀𝒙,𝒚∈ℝdk.formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥subscript𝑯𝑘𝒙subscript𝑯𝑘𝒚𝐻delimited-∥∥𝒙𝒚for-all𝒙𝒚superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑘\lVert\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x})-\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{y})\rVert\leq H\lVert\bm{x}-\bm{y}\rVert,\quad\forall\;\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{k}}. (11)

Letting ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, we use the following standard inequality in our analysis:

∀𝒙,𝒚∈ℝd:∥𝒙+𝒚∥2≤(1+ϵ)∥𝒙∥2+(1+ϵ−1)∥𝒚∥2.\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\quad\lVert\bm{x}+\bm{y}\rVert^{2}\leq(1+\epsilon)\lVert\bm{x}\rVert^{2}+(1+\epsilon^{-1})\lVert\bm{y}\rVert^{2}. (12)

We define the distortion associated with block k𝑘k at time t𝑡t as

Dkt≔∥𝑮kt−𝑯k​(𝒙kt)∥2≔superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑡superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑮𝑘𝑡subscript𝑯𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡2D_{k}^{t}\coloneqq\left\lVert\bm{G}_{k}^{t}-\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right\rVert^{2}

and, recall, we denote the total distortion at time t𝑡t as Dt=∑k=0KDktsuperscript𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘𝑡D^{t}=\sum_{k=0}^{K}D_{k}^{t}.

In Section 4, we introduced the following sigma-algebra

ℱt=σ​(𝑮0,𝒙1,𝑮1,…,𝒙t,𝑮t),subscriptℱ𝑡𝜎superscript𝑮0superscript𝒙1superscript𝑮1…superscript𝒙𝑡superscript𝑮𝑡\mathcal{F}_{t}=\sigma(\bm{G}^{0},\bm{x}^{1},\bm{G}^{1},\dots,\bm{x}^{t},\bm{G}^{t}),

where 𝑮t={𝑮0t,…,𝑮Kt}superscript𝑮𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑮𝑡0…subscriptsuperscript𝑮𝑡𝐾\bm{G}^{t}=\{\bm{G}^{t}_{0},\dots,\bm{G}^{t}_{K}\}. We now further define

ℱt′≔σ​(𝑮0,𝒙1,𝑮1,…,𝒙t,𝑮t,𝒙t+1).≔subscriptsuperscriptℱ′𝑡𝜎superscript𝑮0superscript𝒙1superscript𝑮1…superscript𝒙𝑡superscript𝑮𝑡superscript𝒙𝑡1\mathcal{F}^{\prime}_{t}\coloneqq\sigma(\bm{G}^{0},\bm{x}^{1},\bm{G}^{1},\dots,\bm{x}^{t},\bm{G}^{t},\bm{x}^{t+1}).

Recall that we let 𝔼σtsubscript𝔼subscript𝜎𝑡\mathbb{E}_{\sigma_{t}} denote the conditional expectation 𝔼[⋅∣σt]\mathbb{E}[\cdot\mid\sigma_{t}] and that δ≔(1−α)∈[0,1)≔𝛿1𝛼01\delta\coloneqq(1-\alpha)\in[0,1).

Note that, while we write our proofs for Algorithm 1, they can be easily adjusted to cover Algorithm 2. To do so, it suffices to adjust the notation, replacing 𝒈tsuperscript𝒈𝑡\bm{g}^{t} and 𝒈~tsuperscript~𝒈𝑡\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t} by ∇ktsubscriptsuperscriptbold-∇𝑡𝑘\bm{\nabla}^{t}_{k} and ∇~ktsubscriptsuperscript~bold-∇𝑡𝑘\tilde{\bm{\nabla}}^{t}_{k}, respectively, and to make minor changes to the proof of Lemma 1, which cause the constant K𝐾K in Lemma 1 to be replaced with K+1𝐾1K+1. This, in turn, leads to a similar adjustment in the constants of our main theorems.

where, recall, 𝒈~ktsuperscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡\tilde{\bm{g}}_{k}^{t} is our (possibly stochastic) update vector. Summing over k=0,1,…,K𝑘01…𝐾k=0,1,\dots,K and taking the nonconditional expectation of both sides of the inequality, we get that

𝔼​Dt+1≤δ​(1+ϵ)​𝔼​Dt+δ​(1+ϵ−1)​η2​H2​𝔼​∥𝒈~t∥2.𝔼superscript𝐷𝑡1𝛿1italic-ϵ𝔼superscript𝐷𝑡𝛿1superscriptitalic-ϵ1superscript𝜂2superscript𝐻2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript~𝒈𝑡2\mathbb{E}D^{t+1}\leq\delta(1+\epsilon)\mathbb{E}D^{t}+\delta(1+\epsilon^{-1})\eta^{2}H^{2}\mathbb{E}\lVert\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}\rVert^{2}.

Lastly, using the fact that, under (A3), (A4) is equivalent to 𝔼​∥𝒈~t∥2≤𝔼​∥𝒈t∥2+σ2B𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript~𝒈𝑡2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝒈𝑡2superscript𝜎2𝐵\mathbb{E}\lVert\tilde{\bm{g}}^{t}\rVert^{2}\leq\mathbb{E}\lVert\bm{g}^{t}\rVert^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{B}, we arrive at (7).

Appendix C Main Theorems

First, let us define some shorthand notation for terms we will be using throughout our proof, whose expectation is with respect to the (possible) randomness in the compression across all steps:

(compression error) Ω1t≔𝔼​Dt,≔superscriptsubscriptΩ1𝑡𝔼superscript𝐷𝑡\displaystyle\Omega_{1}^{t}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}D^{t},
(surrogate norm) Ω2t≔𝔼​∥𝒈t∥2.≔superscriptsubscriptΩ2𝑡𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝒈𝑡2\displaystyle\Omega_{2}^{t}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}\lVert\bm{g}^{t}\rVert^{2}.

Bounding η𝜂\eta and choosing ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

To ensure that 𝒲ϵsubscript𝒲italic-ϵ\mathcal{W}_{\epsilon} is not empty, we need

η2​γ​(ϵ)​L2+η​L≤1whereγ​(ϵ)≔K​H4​δ​(1+ϵ−1)1−δ​(1+ϵ).formulae-sequencesuperscript𝜂2𝛾italic-ϵsuperscript𝐿2𝜂𝐿1where≔𝛾italic-ϵ𝐾superscript𝐻4𝛿1superscriptitalic-ϵ11𝛿1italic-ϵ\eta^{2}\gamma(\epsilon)L^{2}+\eta L\leq 1\quad\text{where}\quad\gamma(\epsilon)\coloneqq KH^{4}\frac{\delta(1+\epsilon^{-1})}{1-\delta(1+\epsilon)}.

From Lemma 5 of Richtárik et al. (2021), we know that, if a,b>0𝑎𝑏0a,b>0, then 0≤η≤1a+b0𝜂1𝑎𝑏0\leq\eta\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{a}+b} implies a​η2+b​η≤1𝑎superscript𝜂2𝑏𝜂1a\eta^{2}+b\eta\leq 1. Thus, we can ensure that 𝒲ϵsubscript𝒲italic-ϵ\mathcal{W}_{\epsilon} is not empty by requiring

η≤1γ​(ϵ)​L2+L=(γ​(ϵ)​L+L)−1.𝜂1𝛾italic-ϵsuperscript𝐿2𝐿superscript𝛾italic-ϵ𝐿𝐿1\eta\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{\gamma(\epsilon)L^{2}}+L}=\left(\sqrt{\gamma(\epsilon)}L+L\right)^{-1}.

Note that, for α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, we recover η≤1/L𝜂1𝐿\eta\leq 1/L.

Choosing w𝑤w.

Now, since f⋆≤f​(𝒙)superscript𝑓⋆𝑓𝒙f^{\star}\leq f(\bm{x}) for all 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} and Ω1T≥0superscriptsubscriptΩ1𝑇0\Omega_{1}^{T}\geq 0, we have from (15) that

∀w∈𝒲ϵ:1T∑t=0T−1𝔼∥∇f(𝒙t)∥2≤2​Δη​T+2​w​Ω10η​T+(2wδ(1+ϵ−1)H2+L)η​σ2B,\forall w\in\mathcal{W}_{\epsilon}\colon\quad\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{t})\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{2\Delta}{\eta T}+\frac{2w\Omega_{1}^{0}}{\eta T}+\left(2w\delta(1+\epsilon^{-1})H^{2}+L\right)\frac{\eta\sigma^{2}}{B},

1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​∥∇f​(𝒙t)∥2≤2​Δη​T+K​H2​L21−1−α⋅𝔼​D0T+(η​L​ρα​1+1)​η​L​σ2B.1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓superscript𝒙𝑡22Δ𝜂𝑇⋅𝐾superscript𝐻2superscript𝐿211𝛼𝔼superscript𝐷0𝑇𝜂𝐿subscript𝜌𝛼11𝜂𝐿superscript𝜎2𝐵\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x}^{t})\rVert^{2}\leq\frac{2\Delta}{\eta T}+\frac{KH^{2}L^{2}}{1-\sqrt{1-\alpha}}\cdot\frac{\mathbb{E}D^{0}}{T}+\left(\eta L\rho_{\alpha 1}+1\right)\frac{\eta L\sigma^{2}}{B}.

C.2 Proof of Theorem 2

Recall that, using the Ω1tsuperscriptsubscriptΩ1𝑡\Omega_{1}^{t} and Ω2tsuperscriptsubscriptΩ2𝑡\Omega_{2}^{t} notation, we can rewrite (7) and (13), respectively, as
